subNodes.conversationText: That Ianth woman acts like she owns this town.  Ha!
The other tonwsfolk might be afraid of her, but my sword arm's never been outdone by a woman's.
The three of us belong to Saern's Swords--the town's real protectors.
If there was work to do, we'd be doing it...But Danmar has deep cups, and Miss Lavillus always beats us to it anyway.
I hear Ianth is a duchess, or a princess, or a queen, or...some such thing.  Whatever she is, she don't know the ways of the Backlands like we do.
My, my, if it isn't Miss Lavillus.  I can't believe we're even being graced with her presence!
You're a forward little blighter, Carver--always have been. Ha! Good to lay eyes on you again, Miss Lavillus. [Sarcastically.] Melincourt is always at your service.
[Affectedly.] Why, Miss Lavillus, I do think you look exceptional this eve; may your humble servant Carver kiss thy hand of lily white?
You'd have to stand on your toes to do that, Carver--why not ask for her lily white kneecap instead?
Or 'er lily white--[The big fellow stops when he catches the fierce glint in Ianth's eye.]
Let us leave these clowns to their business, . We have better things to do.

[Suddenly mad.] Now you listen here, Miss Lavillus. You came to town and took all of Saerns' Swords real business unasked--What were we militiamen supposed to do with you parading around in that fancy armor, guarding the path to town and scouting in our stead? You made us look like fools.
I am good at what I do, and, because I was here, I did only what needed to be done for the good of all.  I did not mean to make you look like fools.
Good at what you do, eh? You can carry a sword and kill stray orcs, but you're not a real hunter. You don't belong in the Backlands. You'll never know the land like we do.
Let us leave these men to their cups, Ianth.  You are right: we have better things to do.
That sounds like a challenge, Ianth.
You fools!  Ianth could take the lot of you single-handed.
Ho now!  It seems like Lady Lavillus has bought herself some courtiers.
This <race> <lad/lass> and you are pretty tight, ay?  And what else have we got?
A moustachioed dandy that looks like he'd be better off in the city than out here in the wilderness!  Here's some gossip for you, sir: the Backlands ain't Waterdeep.
And--[Peering down at Gossam] Oh ho, I didn't see the other one! Is this little fellow your long-lost cousin, Carver?
I hope not.  He smells like either a turnip or a priest--I can't decide which.
You're a disgrace to your height, Master Carver.
I am well aware that I am in the Backlands.  Nowhere else in the Realms would such talk as this pass as wit.
[Ambergren, the big fellow, mutters angrily.] Stuck-up city folk.
You and your entourage aren't getting off so easy, Miss Lavillus.  We have a challenge for you.
That's what you think.  Hear me out.
Tell on.  What is this challenge?
Saern's Swords have been protecting Drawn Swords for years.  We're warriors, hunters, and men of the field and woods.  I've killed as many boar in my lifetime as there are folk in this town.
Then you've killed a total of three or so?  That doesn't seem like many.
[Melincourt does not seem to have heard you.]

[Solemnly.] In all my time of hunting and fighting, though, there's one beast who's always eluded me. The Backlands Boar. I fought him once--and he gored me and left me for dead. Ilmater willed that I got back to town all right, but I've owed him one ever since.
Hey Melincourt, why don't you tell them all where you got gored?!  You could show them the scar, too.
Shut up, you half-tanked and half-witted half-man!

That boar is still alive.  This I know for a fact; some say he's dead, but he's at least a hundred years old, and I'll wager he'll live another hundred.  By my stones, I've seen him twice since I fought him in the Backlands, in a clearing north of town.
You are challenging us to track down this "Backlands Boar," I take it.

Yes.  My da told me stories of the Backlands Boar when I was as little as Carver; it's stronger and older and deadlier than any other boar in the Backlands.  I challenge you and Miss Lavillus to kill it.  That'd go a long way to prove that Miss Lavillus deserves to be protector of Drawn Swords.
This, then, is your challenge?  Find this boar and do the deed you could not?
If this is your challenge, then, I accept. Far be it from any Knight of the Ruby Rose to refuse an honorable challenge.
Good then.  I'll be waiting here--bring back its head.
Ianth, we do not need to prove anything to these men.
I know, but the challenge was honorable.  Besides, if Melincourt and his crew learn a lesson from this it will be for their own good.
I am surprised you think those louts worth your time, Ianth.
If they are supposed to have been the protectors of Drawn Swords once, it may be that it is for the town's best interest that they be educated.  Is that what you are thinking, Ianth?
Precisely, Gossam.  You are quite perceptive.
Though it seem strange to say, it is for the best; and I do it on behalf of the town as well as my own pride.  But come: we have even more to do now than we did before.
I hope this challenge involves your heads.
Nay, <FirstName>.  These men were once the protectors of Drawn Swords; it would not be good to brawl with them.  We will be leaving now, Melincourt.
You are entitled to your opinion, of course; but I hope you do not expect that it will keep me from my duty.  Come, <FirstName>.
I see you still haven't got that head.  No surprise, really...Ha!
So tell me--have you and Ianth beaten that boar yet?
In a sense.  We met the creature, but decided against killing it.
You expect me to believe that?  Why, how do I know you even saw it?!  Ha!
I believe it: Miss Lavillus walked up to the beast, shot it one of her famous dirty looks, and off he went, as fast as Talos's spear!
[Ambergren guffaws in approval.] That ain't right, that ain't right. Ha!

You can believe what you wish.  The creature was old and unfit for battle; killing it would have been cruel if there was any way of avoiding it--luckily for us, I have one skilled in the ways of the wild in my party.
But not very impressed.  I'd say it's time for another challenge, Miss Lavillus.
Perhaps, but I'm not ready to talk about it right now.  Farewell.
You return at last--don't tell me you and Ianth have actually done it?!
[Open your sack and show Melincourt the huge and impressive head of the Backlands Boar.]

Why, that's the Backlands Boar all right!--as real as a swig of Moonshavian whiskey and as handsome as a cup of the same. [Melincourt takes the head, looks at it again in awe, and hands you a few gold pieces.]
[Open your sack and reveal the bloody pulp of the Backland Boar's head.]
Well, it looks something like the Backlands Boar, but it also looks something like a beaten horse.
When's the last time you saw a horse in this part of the Backlands, Melincourt?  Looks real enough to me.
[A little distantly.] Well, I'll be damned. After all this time...And you mean to tell me you helped bring this brute down, Miss Lavillus?
I fought as well as it became me to fight.
[Ambergren mumbles in agreement.] I'll wager it's nonsense, all right.
[Suddenly bristling.] That's right, Miss Lavillus! Make fools of us all over again, eh?--Me, and Ambergren, and little Carver!--And my Da, who went and told me about the Boar in the first place--
--Well he told me there was no man who could beat it, and here you've gone and made a fool of him, Ilmater keep his bones!
Aw Melincourt, don't get upset. We're still the real muscle in Drawn Swords; if the three of us had ever had to face that boar, you can bet we'd have a head to show for ourselves too.
I say this contest isn't over yet. How about a little arm-wrestling--Ambergren versus Ianth? I'll put down fifty gold.
[Ianth looks cooly at Ambergren, sizing him up. Though large, he is soft from drinking and inactivity.] Very well. I agree to this new challenge.
Why do you think so, <FirstName>?  Even if these men never learn, I think it ought to be my duty to try to teach them something.
Because, Ianth--After you leave Drawn Swords, these men will be all Drawn Swords has to serve as guardians.  They need their pride back.
Ah....I understand.  I did not see it that way before, but you are right.  You should do it.
You have already met the terms of their contest.  It is not right that they try to force a new challenge on you at this point.  Let me take this one on.
They have broken their terms; it would disgrace you to stoop to their level.  I will arm-wrestle in your stead, Milady.
So very courteous you are.  So be it, <FirstName>.  You can fight on my behalf.
You might be able to defeat him, but I definitely can.
I heard that.  This upstart <lad/lass>, the little page of Lady Lavillus, wants to give Ambergren a go.  I say: let <him/her>!
If Miss Lavillus wants to back off, why sure.  Get ready Ambergren.  And good luck to you...ha!
[Strength + Intimidate] Indeed. Let's go. [Attempt to beat Ambergren at arm-wrestling.]
[Success] [After a few moments of unsureness, the contest tips in your favor. You have beaten Ambergren!]
[Melincourt looks dejected and uneasy.] Damn, Ambergren, you really have lost it, haven't you? Ever since Miss Lavillus arrived in town, we've drunk ourselves soft.
Well, you have only yourselves to blame.  Now, I believe someone said something about gold.
So Miss Lavillus has swindled of us of our jobs and livelihood.  You'd think her pa would have had enough money for the lot of you--eh well.  Carver, pay the <lord/lady> that fifty gold.
[Glumly.] It's a sad day for me--this money was going to warm me for the next few nights. Ah well, I guess I have no choice.
Alas, the three of us are a sorry lot.

[Carver hands you fifty golds, and Melincourt bids you farewell.] There won't be much better for us to do than sit around here and drink, but that don't mean we'll welcome your company. You and Miss Lavillus can go off and save the world together--But don't expect any kindness from this quarter.
You know, Melincourt, it needn't stay that way.  Ianth will not be here forever, and when she goes, you will still have your duty to the town.
It's not only us that have forgotten our duty to Drawn Swords--our hands and swords don't remember how to work right.  Well, I suppose it's time for us to move on.
I guess this means we have to stop drinking, eh?
[Ambergren mumbles sadly.] Aye, I think you've guessed it.

[Melincourt bids you farewell.] Come, you two. Miss Lavillus might have shown us up in some ways, but that doesn't mean we don't have the stones to keep on living and doing what we do best for Drawn Swords. Off we go.
Why don't you give the cups a rest, then?  You owe it to yourselves.

Owe it to ourselves?  An interesting way of putting it, but I suppose it makes some sort of sense.  We owe it to Drawn Swords, too, come to think of it; old Hamfast hasn't been pleased with us, and good ol' Saern wouldn't be pleased with us either.
[Failure] [It does not take too long for Ambergren's formidable strength and will to overpower yours.]
All right, then. [Let Ambergren beat you at arm-wrestling.]
[It does not take long for the formidable fist of Ambergren to force yours down--not that you didn't intend it to...]
[Whistling.] Whew-wee! Well, it looks like you've still got that fire in your belly, Ambergren. Does me good to see that we can show up Miss Lavillus and her friend.
True enough: this <lad/lass> who's come face to face with the Backlands Boar can't take down good old Ambergren--the ox!
[In a deep, proud growl.] That's right!
It's almost enough to make a man leave his cups for good.
You know, Melincourt, that's not a bad idea.  Ianth and I aren't going to stay in the area forever.
You're right.  Saern himself wouldn't be too proud of us, and I know Hamfast isn't happy about us whittling away our noggins in here.  What do you say, boys?
Perhaps you ought to leave your cups.  The good of Drawn Swords might depend on it some day.
Damn--I don't know how I lost!
Ha! Well lose you did, my friend.

Meanwhile, I've been thinking:  Saern himself wouldn't be too proud of us drinking ourselves silly in his good name, and I know Hamfast isn't happy about us whittling away our noggins.  What do you say, boys?  Back to work?
I guess this means we have to stop drinking, eh?
[Ambergren mumbles sadly.] Aye, I think you've guessed it.

[Melincourt bids you farewell.] Come, you two. Miss Lavillus might have shown us up in some ways, but that doesn't mean we don't have the stones to keep on living and doing what we do best for Drawn Swords. Off we go.
What are you doing, <FirstName>?  They challenged me.
[After a mere few seconds of unsureness, the arm-wrestling contest tips easily in Ianth's favor.]
So Miss Lavillus has swindled of us of our jobs and livelihood.  You'd think her pa would have had enough money for the lot of you--eh well.  Carver, pay the <lord/lady> that fifty gold.
[Glumly.] It's a sad day for me--this money was going to warm me for the next few nights. Ah well, I guess I have no choice.
Alas, the three of us are a sorry lot.

[Carver hands you fifty golds, and Melincourt bids you farewell.] There won't be much better for us to do than sit around here and drink, but that don't mean we'll welcome your company. You and Miss Lavillus can go off and save the world together--But don't expect any kindness from this quarter.
You know, Melincourt, it needn't stay that way.  Ianth will not be here forever, and when she goes, you will still have your duty to the town.
I don't want to hear anything more out of you.
Why don't you give the cups a rest, then?  You owe it to yourselves.
Yes, Melincourt, we have met the terms of your challenge.  Behold the Backlands Boar!
Yes, Melincourt, we have met the terms of your challenge.  Behold the Backlands Boar!
Perhaps, but I'm not ready to talk about it right now.  Farewell.
Go away.  Drinking is better than talking to you.
